children.name: description
children.definition: a piece of writing or speech that gives details about what sb or sth is like : sự mô tả, bản mô tả
examples: description of
an accurate description of the event
The booklet gives a brief description of each place.
Berlin sounds fascinating from your description.

children.name: give
children.definition: somebody
examples: a descriptionShe was unable to give the police a description of her attacker.

children.name: provide a descriptionformal
examples: The diary provides a clear description of farming life in the 1850s.

children.name: issue a description
children.definition: formally give a description of someone to the public
examples: Police have issued a description of the two men they are looking for.

children.name: fit/match a description
children.definition: be like the person in a police description
examples: The first man they arrested did not fit the description given by the victim.

children.name: somebody answering a description
children.definition: a person who looks like someone in a police description
examples: A young girl answering this description has been seen in Spain.

children.name: good
examples: Her descriptions of the natural world are very good.

children.name: clear
examples: He gave us a clear description of the situation in the city.

children.name: detailed
examples: Some of his descriptions of the island are very detailed.

children.name: accurate
examples: I don't think the hotel's description of its facilities was very accurate.

children.name: vivid
children.definition: very clear and interesting
examples: The book contains some vivid descriptions of his childhood.

children.name: perfect
examples: We have a perfect description of the man we are looking for.

children.name: a full descriptionformal
children.definition: detailed
examples: Please give a full description of your responsibilities in your present job.

children.name: a long/lengthy description
examples: I didn't want to hear a lengthy description of their holiday.

children.name: a brief/short description
examples: There's only a brief description of the hotel on the Internet.

children.name: a general description
children.definition: not detailed
examples: He started by giving us a general description of the manufacturing process.

children.name: a graphic description
children.definition: very clear and containing a lot of details, usually about something unpleasant
examples: The book has some graphic descriptions of life in the prison camp.

children.name: report
children.definition: a written or spoken account of a situation or event, giving people the information they need, especially after studying something as part of your job :bản báo cáo, bản tường trình
examples: Initial police reports suggest she was murdered.

children.name: write a report
examples: Her social worker has written a report on the case.

children.name: make a report
examples: We make regular progress reports to our manager.

children.name: give a report
children.definition: make a report, usually a spoken one
examples: He came to the office to give his report in person.

children.name: prepare a report
examples: The surveyor will view the property and prepare a full report.

children.name: submit a reportformal
children.definition: give a written report to someone
examples: Doctors will have to submit weekly reports.

children.name: a report says/states
children.definition: that
examples: The report said that it would cost another £250 million to repair the damage.

children.name: a full/detailed report
examples: A full report will be prepared for the next committee meeting.

children.name: an official/formal report
examples: Black graduates still face discrimination from employers, according to an official report.

children.name: a written report
examples: Mr Thomas asked me to send him a written report.

children.name: a confidential report
children.definition: one that only a few people see
examples: He made a confidential report to UN headquarters in New York.

children.name: an autopsy report
children.definition: alsoa post-mortem reportBritish English
examples: (= that shows the results of an examination on a dead body to find the cause of death )The autopsy report gave the cause of death as alcohol poisoning.

children.name: report of/on/about
examples: Colleges have to provide a written report on the progress of each student during the year.

children.name: account
children.definition: a written or spoken description that says what happens in an event or process : kê khai, báo cáo, mô tả
examples: Chomsky’s account of how children learn their first language
account of
He was too shocked to give an account of what had happened.

children.name: give an account
examples: Marshall gave the police his account of how the fight started.

children.name: provide an account
examples: Freud has provided an account of the human psyche’s stages of development.

children.name: write an account
examples: He later wrote an account of his experiences during the war.

children.name: read an account
examples: Have you read his account of the journey?

children.name: a detailed account
examples: She gave me a detailed account of what happened at the meeting.

children.name: a full account
examples: It is not possible to give a full account of what we discussed.

children.name: a short account
examples: What follows is a short account of the legal procedure.

children.name: a brief account
examples: The class were asked to write a brief account of their holidays.

children.name: a clear account
examples: I’ve tried to write a clear account of the incident.

children.name: an accurate account
examples: Both newspapers gave fairly accurate accounts of what had happened.

children.name: a true account
examples: The book is a true account of his life and death.

children.name: a blow-by-blow account
children.definition: very detailed
examples: Rosemary gave me a blow-by-blow account of their trip.

children.name: a graphic account
children.definition: very clear with a lot of details, especially unpleasant details
examples: He wrote a graphic account of his time in jail.

children.name: a vivid account
children.definition: so clear that it seems real or like real life
examples: I read a vivid account of his experiences in Egypt.

children.name: an eye-witness account
children.definition: an account of an event, given by the person who saw it happen
examples: an eye-witness account of the attack

children.name: a first-hand account
children.definition: an account of a situation, given by the person who experienced it
examples: a first-hand account of life in the refugee camps

children.name: conflicting accounts
children.definition: different accounts of the same event, that cannot both be true
examples: There were conflicting accounts of what actually happened.

children.name: portrayal
children.definition: a description of a person, thing, place etc that deliberately chooses particular details about them in order to make people form a particular opinion about them, especially a bad opinion: chân dung
examples: portrayal of
the newspapers’ portrayal of Islamic culture
Many have criticized Hollywood for its unrealistic portrayal of life in America.
accurate/realistic etc portrayal
The film is not an accurate portrayal(= correct portrayal )of his life.
portrayal of sb/sth as
I cannot accept the article’s portrayal of these men as bloodthirsty terrorists.

children.name: version
children.definition: sb’s version of an event is their description of it, when this is different from the description given by another person : bản thuật lại
examples: Could Donna’s version of what happened that night be correct?
version of events
according to the official version of events
Her version of events has been contradicted by other witnesses.

children.name: profile
children.definition: a short description of sb’s life, work, and character, especially of sb famous, that is written in a newspaper, shown on television etc: hồ sơ

children.name: profile of
examples: Every week the magazine presents the profile of a well-known sports personality.
I heard a fascinating profile of Madeleine Albright on the radio yesterday.

children.name: case study
children.definition: a detailed account of the development of a particular person, group, or situation that has been studied over a period of time : nghiên cứu tình huống, điều tra mẫu
examples: This is an interesting psychiatric case study of a child with extreme behavioural difficulties.

children.name: stories intended to teach people sth
allegory
children.definition: a story in which the events and characters represent sth or sb else from the real world: phúng dụ, ngụ ngôn
examples: "Animal Farm' is an allegory in which the animals represent the Russian people and Farmer Jones the old Tsarist regime.

children.name: allegory of
examples: The film was a dark, powerful allegory of life in post-war America.

children.name: parable
children.definition: a short simple story that is used to teach something, especially what is morally right : ngụ ngôn
examples: Christ used parables to explain moral questions in a way that people could understand.
It is a kind of parable for the eighties -- a lesson about the destructiveness of greed.
parable of
the parable of ‘The Prodigal Son’

children.name: fable
children.definition: a traditional imaginary short story that teaches a moral lesson, especially a story about animals : truyền thuyết, ngụ ngôn

children.name: the fable of the tortoise and the hare|a Chinese fable
examples: The best-known of Aesop’s fables is "The Tortoise and the Hare'.
The life of Howard Hughes cannot fail to remind us of the fable of Midas.

children.name: plot
children.definition: the events that form the main story of a book, film, or play: cốt truyện
examples: The plot was so complicated that I was totally confused by the time I was two chapters in.
The book doesn’t have much of a plot, but its characters are fantastic.
The plot was a little confusing.
We discover that Jack isn’t as innocent as he seems, as theplot unfolds(= gradually becomes clearer ).
The film has a very simple plot.
The plotsofhis books are basically all the same.

children.name: storyline
children.definition: the main story of a book, play, film etc: cốt truyện
examples: Anna’s marriage problems form the main storyline in Episode One.
The storyline was too far-fetched, and none of the actors were particularly good.
The play had a strong story line.

children.name: strand
children.definition: a part which combines with other parts to form a whole story, subject or situation : tuyến phát triển, mạch
examples: There are so many different strands to the plot that it's quite hard to follow.

children.name: thread
children.definition: the thread of a book, discussion, speech, etc. is its story or the way that it develops, one part connecting with another: dòng, mạch
examples: One of the main threads of the film is the development of the relationship between the boy and his uncle.
athread running throughthe film
acommon threadrunning within his work
lost the thread
Unfortunately my attention wandered for a moment and I lost the thread of what I was saying.
His mind wandered, and he lost the thread of what she was saying.
thread of
a thread of spirituality in her work

children.name: the story of your own life
life story
children.definition: an account, especially a spoken account, of the main events that have happened in sb’s life:
examples: When you meet someone for the first time, they don’t want your entire life story in detail.
The newspaper has been running his life story for the past two weeks.
The last time you sat me next to Alberto I had to hear his whole life story!

children.name: tell your life story
examples: She insisted on telling me her whole life story .

children.name: story of your life
children.definition: a spoken account of the main events that have happened in your life, especially if they are boring or unpleasant:

children.name: tell sb the story of your life
examples: He told me the story of his life right from the early days in a poor part of Washington.

children.name: She began to tell him the story of her life, a long catalogue of disappointment and gloom
tale
children.definition: a story about strange imaginary events, or exciting events that happened in the past : chuyện kể
examples: a fairy tale by Hans Christian Andersen
tale of
‘Treasure Island’ - a tale of pirates and adventure

children.name: a fairy taletruyện thần tiên
examples: It looked like a castle in a fairy tale.

children.name: a folk talechuyện dân gian
children.definition: a traditional story
examples: a book of Scottish folk tales

children.name: a cautionary tale
children.definition: one that is told to warn sb about the dangers of sth
examples: chuyện cảnh báoThis cautionary tale illustrates the dangers of looking for quick profits.

children.name: a tall tale
children.definition: one that is difficult to believe and unlikely to be true
examples: chuyện bịa đặtShe enjoyed making up tall tales to tell the children.

children.name: tell a tale
examples: He liked telling tales of his adventures in the wilderness.

children.name: legend
children.definition: an old well-known story, often about brave people, adventures, or magical events →myth: thần thoại
examples: a book of ancient Greek legends
legend of
the legend of St George and the dragon
according to legend
According to legend, he escaped by leaping from the cliffs into the sea.
a Greek/Roman/Celtic etc legendthe figure of Hercules in Greek legend

children.name: an old/ancient legend
examples: You will have heard the old legend about how the rocks were formed.

children.name: a local legend
examples: According to a local legend, the tree was planted by a wizard.

children.name: a popular legend
children.definition: one that many people believe
examples: A popular legend grew up about him.

children.name: Arthurian legend
children.definition: s
examples: (= the legends about King Arthur of Britain )The castle of Camelot plays an important role in Arthurian legend.

children.name: become legend/pass into legend
examples: The incident became legend.

children.name: a legend grew
children.definition: up
examples: (= developed over time )The legend of his bravery grew after he killed the dragon.

children.definition: the
examples: legend saysLegend says King Arthur’s sword was thrown into one of the pools here.

children.name: the legend tells how
examples: The legend tells how the King of Troy offended Poseidon, the sea god.

children.name: the legend goes
children.definition: says
examples: Two people, so the legend goes, refused to flee.

children.name: a legend is attached to something
children.definition: connected with it
examples: The cave has an unusual legend attached to it.

children.name: legend has it that
children.definition: says that
examples: Legend has it that Rhodes was home to the sun god Helios.

children.name: be the subject of legend
children.definition: alsobe the stuff of legend
examples: (= have stories told about them )The island has long been the subject of legend.

children.name: myths and legends
examples: I read and reread the Greek myths and legends.

children.name: saga
children.definition: a story about a series of connected events or adventures that take place over a long period of time, especially events involving one family: Xaga (truyện dân gian của các (dân tộc) Bắc-Âu về một nhân vật, một dòng họ...)
examples: The novel is a historical saga, set in Tudor times.

children.name: saga of
examples: Her saga of the rise and fall of a powerful family dynasty was a great commercial success.

children.name: story
children.definition: for entertainmenta description of how sth happened, that is intended to entertain people, and may be true or imaginary : câu chuyện
examples: story about/of
a story about a princess
an adventure storyan exciting adventure story for children
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'say (somebody) a story'. Saytell (somebody) a story.

children.name: a true story‘
examples: Schindler’s List’ tells the true story of Oskar Schindler.

children.name: a classic story
children.definition: old and admired by many people, or typical and good
examples: a classic story about a little girl who falls down a rabbit hole

children.name: a short story
examples: He has published two collections of short stories.

children.name: a children’s story
examples: Enid Blyton is famous for writing children’s stories.

children.name: a love story‘
examples: Romeo and Juliet’ is a classic love story.

children.name: a fairy story
children.definition: a children's story in which magical things happen
examples: She looked like a princess in a fairy story.

children.name: a detective story
examples: Most detective stories are about a murder.

children.name: a ghost/horror story
examples: They sat round the fire telling ghost stories.|She likes reading horror stories.

children.name: a bedtime story
children.definition: one that you read to a child before they go to sleep
examples: He remembered his mother reading him a bedtime story.

children.name: tell
children.definition: somebody
examples: a storyWould you like me to tell you a story?

children.name: read
children.definition: somebody
examples: a storyShe read a lot of detective stories.

children.name: write a story
examples: The story was written by Lewis Carroll.

children.name: myth
children.definition: an ancient story, especially one invented in order to explain natural or historical events : truyện thần thoại
examples: a book of Greek myths
myth of
the myth of Orpheus
the giants of myth and fairytale
characters from classical mythology
mythology of
the mythology of the Persians
mythical/ mythic[adj] existing only in stories
the mythicalislandofAtlantis
a mythical hero
dragons and other mythical creatures
mythological[adj] connected with myths
a mythological hero/creature

children.name: mythology[
examples: C or U] set of ancient myths :

children.name: story
children.definition: an account of sth that has happened which may not be true – used especially when people are telling each other aboutsth: câu chuyện
examples: Thefull storyof what happened has never been reported.
Her parents did not believe her story.
First, he wanted to hear Matthew’sside of the story(= his description of what happened ).
He was having an affair with Julie, orso the story goes(= people are saying this ).

children.name: tell
children.definition: somebody
examples: a story(alsorecount/relate a storyformal)I'd better tell you the whole story from the beginning.|He laughed as he recounted the story.

children.name: give
children.definition: somebody
examples: a storyI had the feeling that she wasn't giving me the full story.

children.name: hear a story
children.definition: alsolisten to a story
examples: I’ve heard that story a hundred times.

children.name: make up/invent a story
examples: She confessed to making up the story of being abducted.

children.name: stick to your story
children.definition: keep saying it is true
examples: He didn’t believe her at first, but she stuck to her story.

children.name: change your story
examples: During police interviews, Harper changed his story several times.

children.name: believe a story
examples: The jury did not believe Evans's story.

children.name: swap stories
children.definition: tell each other stories
examples: They swapped stories and shared their experiences.

children.name: the story goes
children.definition: this is what is people say happened
examples: The story goes that he was drowned off the south coast, but not everyone believed it.

children.name: a story goes around
children.definition: people tell it to each other
examples: A story went around that she had been having an affair.

children.name: the full/whole story
examples: I did not know the full story.

children.name: a plausible/convincing story
examples: She tried to think up a convincing story to tell her parents.

children.name: a remarkable story
examples: The film tells the remarkable story of their escape from a prison camp.

children.name: an apocryphal story
children.definition: one that is well-known but probably not true
examples: There are many apocryphal stories about him.

children.name: the inside story
children.definition: including facts that are known only to people involved
examples: Though I’d seen the official report, I wanted the inside story.

children.name: sb’s side of the story
children.definition: someone’s account of what happened, which may be different from someone else’s
examples: I would like to give my side of the story.

children.name: tale
children.definition: a description of interesting or exciting things that happened to sb, often one which is not completely true about every detail : câu chuyện (của riêng ai đó)

children.name: tale of/about
examples: I loved hearing tales of his travels.

children.name: tales of her life in post-war Berlin
examples: She told me/invented/concocted a tale about missing the bus to explain her lateness.

children.name: tale of/about how
examples: He was in the middle oftellingme a longtaleabout how he once met the Redskins’ manager.

children.name: tell a tale
examples: He told some fascinating tales about his life in India.

children.name: anecdote
children.definition: a short, often funny story, especially about sth sb has done: chuyện vặt, giai thoại
examples: Personal anecdotes have no place in an academic essay.

children.name: anecdote about
examples: The book is full of amusing anecdotes about his time in the police force.
He told one or two amusing anecdotes about his years as a policeman.

children.name: yarn
children.definition: informala story of adventures, travels etc, usually made more exciting and interesting by adding things that never really happened : chuyện bịa đặt
examples: The old captain would oftenspin(= tell )us ayarnabout life aboard ship.
The movie’s a rattling good yarn and full of action.

children.name: narrative
children.definition: formal

children.name: legendary
children.definition: from a legend : huyền thoại, thần kỳ

children.name: a legendary Greek hero
examples: Was King Arthur a real or a legendary character?

children.name: descriptive
children.definition: a piece of writing that is descriptive contains a lot of details describing what sb or sth is like, rather than telling a story or describing events: tính miêu tả
examples: The book contains many fine descriptive passages about everyday life in China.
When you write your paragraph, include as many descriptive details as possible.

children.name: narrative
children.definition: a  poem
examples: narrative structure
